DOC.HEAD: $adv00
For Release Anytime
AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
On Show: Gallery and Museum Exhibits and Shows
DOC.TEXT: The Detroit Institute of Arts: ``Furniture by Wendell Castle,'' first exhibit of non-traditional furniture designed by the American artist. Through Feb. 5.
Dolan-Maxwell: Frank Stella, ``The Waves.'' Through Jan. 28.
Bergen Museum of Art and Science: Work of Greg Wyatt, fantasy-realist sculptor. Jan. 18-March 25.

National Museum of American Art, Smithsonian Institution: ``Training the Hand and Eye: American Drawings From the Cooper-Hewitt Museum.'' Through Feb. 3.
National Museum of African Art: ``Icons: Ideals and Power in the Art of Africa.'' Through Sept. 3.
Whitney Museum of American Art, Fairfield County: ``The Eighties in Review: Selections From the Permanent Collection of the Whitney Musum of American Art.'' Through Feb. 28.
Terra Museum of American Art: ``Frontier America,'' from the collection of the Buffalo Bill Historical Center. Through Jan. 7.
High Museum of Art: ``Land of Deepest Shade: Photographs of the South by John McWilliams.'' Through Jan. 7. ``Art in Berlin _ 1815-1989.'' Through Jan. 14.
Cleveland Museum of Art: Seascape photographs of Hiroshi Sugimoto. Through Jan. 14.
Minneapolis Institute of Arts: ``The American Craftsman and the European Tradition 1620-1820.'' Through Dec. 31.

55 Mercer Artists: American abstract artists, 1989. Through Jan. 6.
Marisa Del Re Gallery, Inc.: Paintings by Nobu Fukui. Through mid-January.
Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum: Works of Jenny Holzer, including an electronic display signboard. Through Feb. 11.
New Renaissance Fine Arts Gallery: Radovan Trnavac (Mica), ``In the Present Time.'' Through Jan. 31.
Pace-McGill Gallery: Dennis Oppenheim, early conceptual work. Through Jan. 6.
Cooper-Hewitt Museum: ``The Intimate World of Alexander Calder.'' Through March 11.
National Academy of Design: ``Treasures From the Fitzwilliam Museum,'' includes paintings by Titian, Hogarth, Degas, Renoir, Rembrandt. Through Jan. 28.
Salander-O'Reilly Galleries Inc.: Works by John Constable, Eugene Delacroix and Paul Rubens. Through Dec. 30.
Prisunic Gallery: Simon Bocanegra, ``Hot Couture.'' Through Dec. 23.
Whitney Museum of American Art: Thomas Hart Benton retrospective. Through Jan. 31. ``Image World: Art and Media Culture.'' Through Feb. 18.
Washburn Gallery: Richard Benson, ``Photographs in Paint.'' Through Jan 2.
Nerlino Gallery: Georgie Papageorge. Through Dec. 30.
Federal Hall National Memorial: ``A.J. Davis and American Classicism.'' Through Dec. 29.
Metropolitan Museum of Art: Compositions by Diego Rodriquez de Silva y Velazquez, including his ``An Old Woman Cooking Eggs'' (1618) with its haunting reality, and ``The Forge of Vulcan'' and ``Joseph's Coat,'' two large works painted during a trip to Italy in 1629-31. Through Jan. 7.
Museum of Modern Art: ``Picasso and Braque: Pioneering Cubism.'' Through Jan. 16.
New York Historical Society: ``An American Sampler: Folk Art From the Shelburne Museum,'' featuring more than 120 works from the Vermont museum's Americana collection. Through Jan. 7. ``Cased Images: The 150th Anniversary of Photography.'' Through Jan. 7. ``Irving Browning: City of Contrasts.'' Through Jan. 7.

Phoenix Art Museum: ``Sino-Tibetan Bronzes.'' Through Dec. 31. ``Napoleon the Great: Selections From the David Markham Collection.'' Through March 25.
Meseo Chicano: ``Arte, Sweat and Tears,'' featuring works of Arizona Hispanic artists and of Mexican painter Jose Luis Cuevas. Through Jan. 15.
Heard Museum: ``Exotic Illusions: Art, Romance and the Marketplace.'' Selections from the Heard's permanent collection demonstrate how artists from Africa, Oceania and the Americas have produced exotic materials for external consumption: pottery, carvings, paintings, jewelry. Through Dec. 31. ``Fourth Biennial Native American Fine Arts Invitational,'' showcasing eight Indian artists from the United States and Canada. Through spring.
Seattle Art Musuem: ``Beyond the Spirit Path: Ceramic Art From the Tombs of China.'' Through Dec. 31.

Dallas Museum of Art: ``Philip Guston: 50 Years of Painting.'' Through Jan. 14. ``Like a One-Eyed Cat: Photographs by Lee Friedlander, 1956-1987,'' an exhibit of more than 100 black and white photos, reflecting his taste for jazz and blues music. Through Jan. 14. ``American Art, 1700 to 1950.'' Through April 8.

Amon Carter Museum: ``Eyewitness to War,'' prints and daguerreotypes of the Mexican War, 1846-1848. Through Jan. 14. ``American Prints: Recent Acquisitions.'' Through Feb. 18.
Kimbell Art Museum: ``The Consul Smith Collection: Rafael to Canaletto Masterpieces From the Royal Library, Windsor Castle.'' Through Jan. 21.
Mesa Southwest Museum: ``The Train Show: 100 Years of Model Railroading.'' Through Feb. 25.
M.H. de Young Memorial Museum: ``California Colorists: Society of Six.'' Through Dec. 31.

Museum of Fine Arts: ``The Grand Elegance Venice: Costumes of Mariano Fortuny.'' More than 50 gowns, costumes and accessories created by Venetian painter, engraver, theater designer and photographer Fortuny (1871-1949). Through Dec. 31. ``Masterworks of Chinese Paintings From the Forbidden City.'' Through Dec. 31. ``The Intimate Interiors of Edouard Vuillard.'' Through Jan. 28.
